page.title: 11Local History in Yewdale 2
page.content: Our local history is associated very strongly with agricultural development, as well as the mining mentioned on P 10. The remarkable fact is that many of our ancestors would be familiar with the present ways of farming. Sheep grazing on open fells are an aspect of hill farming that cannot readily be changed whatever the new developments may be. The impact of this grazing over many centuries, coupled with the extensive felling of trees for charcoal, has made the upper fells largely bare of trees, and has encouraged the growth of bracken. Farmers who can flourish in such a harsh environment have always been sturdily independent, and such men, with their individual approach and 'feel' for the land, gave rise to the {'statesmen'}- the Cumbrian equivalent of the yeoman farmers.
